I'm back up another exciting thing that
we've recently announced just in preview as of yesterday was the ability to run
RDS in your own data center sometimes customer will say hey I really like RDS I like the idea of a managed database I
like taking care of all the patching and versioning and provisioning but I've got databases that I don't necessarily want
to put in to the a Debus cloud maybe you know it's it's it's not right now or you know more sensitive information so we've
announced and and launched a preview of Amazon RDS running in vSphere clusters
and really you get the same characteristics that I talked about an RDS that automation of the database
cloud backups and scaling as well as the ability to easily migrate so if one
thing you can do with Amazon RDS for VMware is you can actually run the database in your data center and
replicate up to the cloud and so if you're planning a migration that's a really nice way to sort of bridge the
gap between what's running locally and what's running in AWS you get the same management console so if you go to your
RDS console you'll see your your your database is running in AWS as well as
running in your own vSphere cluster read replicas performance monitoring the same
characteristics you get in RDS but running on your own hardware will support my sequel and Postgres in the
preview will eventually get to all the open source and commercial engines so
how does this work so the first thing you do is you get RDS from vmware set up
and you deploy something called the connector and the connector is the bridge between your vSphere cluster and
AWS so that's the thing that basically handles the traffic going back and forth and there's a
dedicated VPN tunnel so all the information all of the operations that I'm doing in the console the API is that
I'm calling all of that gets pushed down into my my data center and then in your
data center we're using the standard vSphere cluster to spin up two instances
to spin up read replicas to handle backups you can do backups both locally
within your own data center or you can push those backups to the cloud so a nice way to get a hybrid environment
that we talked about this morning you know for customers who were running on
both on Prem as well in in AWS there is out oh there's a session tomorrow if you
want to get a lot more details on Amazon RDS on VMware so configuring H a high
availability in Amazon RDS is is very easy and our goal was really to make it a single push button so you didn't have
a when you went to production then it was a really easy choice to make so multi AZ configurations take your entire
database and replicate the stack into a second availability zone a second data center and now each of those copies is
managing a full EBS volume with a copy of the data and that data is kept up synchronously so you can be guaranteed
that any rights that you make in the primary are replicated into the secondary so you're not going to lose
any data if something happens in the primary to the primary instance where the order D or the data center overall
now when it's running the instances are being watch or being monitored by an
external observer and it's making sure that who's keeping track of who's in charge so let's say your application
here on the right your application is talking to the the primary the master database that's replicating over to the
the standby and then the primary disappears maybe there's a a volume failure or there's a network span outage
or you know something happens to the instance and you know an infrastructure problem so you'll you'll get a
disconnect we will then promote the secondary to become the new primary and then we will
set backup replication because we want to get it back into a high availability mode so we'll set up replication back to
another availability zone will spin that up and we'll start replicating back now that could be the same instance that is
now recovered so we can we can use that with the same volumes or it could be a new instance so we'll spin that up and
get it configured to make sure that you're you're not losing any of that availability your application then goes
to route 53 ask for what's the address of the the database what's the IP
address gets that new IP address of the new primary and then connects to that usually this takes about a minute to a
minute and a half for the full failover one thing in multi a-z configurations is that the database is not running on the
secondary that's one of the misconceptions sometimes people get the the secondary we don't really start the
database until the failover occurs so it does take a little bit of time to start that up and that's different for example
in an Aurora cluster where the secondary the standby instances are always running they're running and connected in a multi
AZ configuration we don't launch it until the failover happens the other
thing that you'll want to do is if you're using multi AZ you'll want to make sure that your applications have the time to live on the DNS entries very
low I think we usually recommend about a second so in that's that's so they can go back to route 53 and get the new IP
address in the case of a failure the last point here is that this is really
about handling infrastructure issues networking storage compute it's not
database engine problems so if the my sequel engine or the Postgres engine say a workload related runs out of memory
and or has a bug in the in the the open source engine and falls over that's not
going to trigger a multi AZ failover because it would just failover to an instance that you know is basically in
the same situation so we don't trigger that for database engine specific thing rather we trigger that for
infrastructure issues another feature that Amazon RDS makes easy is to gain
read scalability so let's say you give out an application and you're doing reads and writes to your database and
you're starting to see some some peak on the CPU and you're starting to to see some slowdown what you can do is
you can spin up a reed replica the EBS base engine support Thor Postgres my
sequel and Reedy B support up to five Reed replicas for per master you can see
you know that it's a synchronous replication so you can monitor the lag which is the the difference between the
time I write something on the master to the time it comes up on the replica so you can watch that in in cloud watch and
then you can use that Reed replica for Reed scaling for big queries that you want to run so you can partition your
workload and use that Reed replica we have just recently launched a reed
replica for Oracle Enterprise Edition that's in preview now so it uses a data
guard and but it uses the same infrastructure so now you get the same reed replicate capability that you do
with my sequel murray DB and Postgres we will also be doing the same for sequel server very soon so we'll be using the
always on technology and sequel server to provide the same read scalability for sequel server so we're excited to to be
able to launch that another great use of replicas is for disaster recovery so the
one I talked about before was primarily for an in region so you've got an application you're running against
multiple replicas in the same region could be in the same AZ or could be across AZ's but you can also use cross
region Reed replicas for disaster recovery and what this does is allows you to keep a hot standby of your
database in another in another AWS region in the case of a disaster now with Reed replicas we don't promote
automatically so we leave that up to you because it's an expensive operation to move your entire infrastructure over to
to another AZ right another region right if you're moving from US East one to
u.s. West two and it's a pretty intrusive operation but but what we do
allow you to do is to configure that Reed replicas for multi AZ so that if you do have a disaster and you want to
switch over to that other region that Reed replica is already configured for high availability so you can see here
what you're actually getting in that configuration is four copies of the data you've got two and your local
availabilities your local region so-so region one here has two copies using multi AC and then
has a reed replica with another copy so you're actually getting four copies running in across both regions and this
is also a way to you can use a feature called delayed replication in my sequel
and that's really good for self-inflicted problems so what you can do is you can say I want the reed replica to be about an hour behind the
the master I don't want it to be right close to it I wanted to be an hour behind and if something really bad
happens to say you drop a table accidentally or you delete you know some valuable information you have this sort
of a logical corruption then you can go and you can use that reed replica that has a lag to it and you can stop it just
before the bad thing happens and then you can start using that and recover so some nice features there for the my
sequel engine for Oracle and sequel server because we don't yet offer across
region read replicas we really recommend that you use cross region backup copies and I'll talk a little bit about that in
the backup section but what you can do is have a periodic job that pushes off those backup copies to another region
and then you can restore it out of that region if anything if anything happens
so I mentioned backups and RDS has sort of two classes of backups we have what
we call automated backups and automated backups you just turn them on and then you can restore to a point in time
anytime in that window so by default it's seven days and you just say I want to keep seven days and you can go back
three days you can go back three days in six hours you get a full ability to rewind and restore from any time in that
window we also support what we call manual snapshots and those are single points in time and you take a snapshot
of your database and you can keep that as long as you want and you can always restore to that particular point in time
now both of these in both of these cases we use s3 to actually store the backup
so we're storing a snapshot plus we're storing transaction logs and usually the transaction logs for point in time are
within about five minutes of the of the master of the the backup right so
you can use that point in time restore up to about five minutes ago we have a property on the instance that will tell
you what the the latest restorable time is so that's really useful to see if there's any lag in those backups now for
backups there's no performance penalty especially if you're using multi a-z configurations so what we're doing is
we're taking the backup the snapshot off of that secondary instance and so there's no impact at all to to the
primary if you're just using in a single availability zone we do have to pause for just a few seconds so we get a
consistent snapshot between all of the volumes but so you'll see a little latency when we take the backup always
in your backup window with a single AC and then I mentioned then you can copy snapshots across region you can copy
them to another account if you want to for safekeeping some of the new features
that we've introduced recently once called retain automated backups so today
until recently if I delete an instance its automated backups just went away and
one that surprised people but two sometimes people make mistakes and they want to actually retrieve their data so
we now have the ability to retain the backup even after you've deleted the instance and I'll show you how that
works in just a sec another couple features we've added are the ability to specify your parameter group values
during your restore we always pick the default parameter groups now you can specify them and the last one is
important for people who are using another region for disaster recovery purposes and that's incremental
encrypted snapshot copy so if you've got an encrypted instance and you're doing backups if you copy those backups to
another region it's done on an incremental basis so only the blocks that have changed since the last time
you took that backup are copied so it really reduces the size of the backups in the other region which you're going
to be charged for so if you're using encrypted databases you can copy those across and and just get that benefits of
incremental storage I'm gonna show you really quick how this works you switch

and make sure that everything's going well in your database we provide a free
automatic cloud watch metrics so we by default push up important metrics about
what's going on on the instance CPU utilization storage utilization memory
utilization your i/o and latency so all these metrics are going up there's a great new feature of cloud watch metrics
that you get a default dashboard for RDS so if you're not sure about you know how to build a dashboard and which things
you should look at cloud watch now has some out-of-the-box dashboards that are that are sort of geared towards each

know get a page or get an email get some sort of alert in the console if it
exceeds that threshold we also have what we call enhanced monitoring and enhanced monitoring is an additional 50 metrics
that have additional things about what's going on on the database host so more
detailed metrics a lot of sort of internal metrics about from the operating system level that help you debug when your database is slow or you
know something you're getting errors back you can get enhanced metrics are available and that's a very low level of
granularity up to one-second intervals so you can get down to the second cloud watch is usually in a five minute
interval we also have integration with many of the third-party tools that support in the AWS ecosystem for both a
cloud watch and enhanced monitoring now if you're troubleshooting performance
problems then we have a new product called Amazon performance insights new feature of RDS originally it came out
four or Postgres is now available for all of the RDS engines with the
exception of sequel server its sequel server is coming so it's available for Oracle my sequel DB Postgres so and what
performance insights does it helps you identify bottlenecks in your database and it does this through sampling an
agent that's running on the database and it's looking at what are the queries that are running and it's it's doing some sampling and saying at this point
in time here's the queries that are running and here's what resource they're blocked on what are they waiting for are
they waiting for CPU are they waiting for another are they blocked by another thread are they waiting on IO or they
i/o bound so you can see within your database sort of what's going on and
then you can slice down you can drill down to the actual sequel statement so let's say you put out a new version of
your application and it used to be that it was hitting an index with a certain
query it's not hitting that index anymore you would see then in performance insights you would see you
know the computation time would go up for that particular query and you could go in and maybe add an index or tune it in in some other way
